Module count
Package count.matek

Class FunctionMinimization

java.lang.Object
count.matek.FunctionMinimization
public class FunctionMinimization
extends Object
This class implements a number of numerical optimization methods for function minimization and root finding in one or multiple dimensions.
Since:
October 26, 2004, 8:22 PM
Author:
Miklós Csűrös

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes 
    Modifier and Type Class Description
    static class  FunctionMinimization.OptimizationException
    Exception thrown when too many iteration in one of the routines.

    Given an n-dimensional point p[] and an n-dimensional direction xi[], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved.

    • zbrent

      public static double zbrent​(DoubleFunction<Double> func, double x1, double x2, double tol)
      Root finding: using Brent's method, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2. The root will be refined until its accuracy is tol. Specifically, the iteration stops when the root is bracketed within an interval of length tol. Based on NR 9.3.
      Parameters:
      func - function to be minimized
      x1 - left bracket for x value
      x2 - right bracket for x value
      tol - bracketing accuracy
      Returns:
      x value that zeros the function within the bracket

    • golden

      public static double[] golden​(double ax, double bx, double cx, DoubleFunction<Double> func, double tol)
      Golden Section search Based on Numerical Recipes 10.1. Given a function func, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and func(bx) is less than both func(ax) and func(cx)), this routine performs a golden section search for the minimum, isolating it to a fractional precision of about tol.
      Parameters:
      ax - bracket interval endpoint
      bx - bracket midpoint
      cx - bracket interval endpoint
      func - the function to be minimized
      tol - relative length for the smaller bracket length for stopping the bracket shrinking (set to sqrt(precision))
      Returns:
      [x,y] where y is minimum function value, and x is its abscissa

    • brent

      public static double[] brent​(double ax, double bx, double cx, DoubleFunction<Double> func, double tol)
      Brent's method of function minimization Based on Numerical Recipes 10.2. Given a function f, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)), this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using Brent's method.
      Parameters:
      ax - bracket interval endpoint
      bx - bracket midpoint
      cx - bracket interval endpoint
      func - the function to be minimized
      tol - relative length for the smaller bracket length for stopping the bracket shrinking (set to sqrt(precision))
      Returns:
      [x,y] where y is minimum function value, and x is its abscissa

    • dbrent

      public static double[] dbrent​(double ax, double bx, double cx, DoubleFunction<Double> f, DoubleFunction<Double> df, double tol)
      Brent's method of function minimization Based on Numerical Recipes 10.2. Given a function f and its derivative function df, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx [such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)], this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using a modification of Brent’s method that uses derivatives.
      Parameters:
      ax - bracket interval endpoint
      bx - bracket midpoint
      cx - bracket interval endpoint
      f - the function to be minimized
      df - first derivative of f
      tol - relative length for the smaller bracket length for stopping the bracket shrinking (set to sqrt(precision))
      Returns:
      [x,y] where y is minimum function value, and x is its abscissa

    • mnbrak

      public static double[] mnbrak​(double ax, double bx, DoubleFunction<Double> func)
      Initial bracketing routine; given starting guesses ax and bx, brackets the minimum. Based on Numerical Recipes 10.1.
      Parameters:
      ax - interval [left] endpoint
      bx - interval [right] endpoint
      func - function for which minimization is needed
      Returns:
      [a,b, c, func(a), func(b), func(c)] with midpoint a<c<b or a>b>c such that f(b)< min(f(a), f(c))

    • lnsrch

      public static boolean lnsrch​(double[] xold, double fold, double[] g, double[] p, double[] x, double[] f, double stpmax, Function<double[],​Double> func)
      Given a point xold[1..n], and a direction p[1..n], finds a new point x[1..n] along the direction p from xold where the function func has decreased sufficiently.
      Parameters:
      xold - starting point
      fold - function value at starting point
      g - gradient at starting point
      p - direction for line search, usually the Newton direction
      x - new point (returned)
      f - new function value (returned)
      stpmax - limits the length of the steps so that you do not try to evaluate the function in regions where it is undefined or subject to overflow
      func - the function
      Returns:
      false on a normal exit. It is true when x is too close to xold. In a minimization algorithm, this usually signals convergence and can be ignored. However, in a zero-finding algorithm the calling program should check whether the convergence is spurious.

    • dfpmin

      public static double dfpmin​(double[] p, double gtol, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> gradient)
      Given a starting point, the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno variant of Davidon-Fletcher-Powell minimization is performed on a function, using its gradient. The routine lnsrch is called to perform approximate line minimizations. Based on Numerical Recipes ch. 10.7
      Parameters:
      p - starting point, also the location of the minimum on return
      gtol - the convergence requirement on zeroing the gradient
      func - the function to be minimized
      Returns:
      the value of the minimum, and p is updated to show its location

    • dfpmin

      public static double dfpmin​(double[] p, double gtol, int dfp_itmax, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> gradient, List<Double> iterations)
      Given a starting point, the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno variant of Davidon-Fletcher-Powell minimization is performed on a function, using its gradient. The routine lnsrch is called to perform approximate line minimizations. Based on Numerical Recipes ch. 10.7
      Parameters:
      p - starting point, also the location of the minimum on return
      gtol - the convergence requirement on zeroing the gradient
      func - the function to be minimized
      iterations - tracks the intermediate function values: one element added per iteration
      Returns:
      the value of the minimum, and p is updated to show its location

    • powell

      public static double powell​(double[] p, double ftol, Function<double[],​Double> func)
      calls powell with unit directions

    • powell

      public static double powell​(double[] p, double ftol, int powell_itmax, Function<double[],​Double> func, List<Double> iterations)
      calls powell with unit directions

    • powell

      public static double powell​(double[] p, double[][] xi, double ftol, Function<double[],​Double> func)
      Minimization of a function func of n variables. Input consists of an initial starting point p[1..n]; an initial matrix xi[1..n][1..n], whose rows contain the initial set of directions (usually the n unit vectors); and ftol, the fractional tolerance in the function value such that failure to decrease by more than this amount on one iteration signals doneness. On output, p is set to the best point found, xi is the then-current direction set. The routine linmin is used. Based on Numerical Recipes ch. 10.5.
      Parameters:
      p - initial point
      xi - initial set of directions
      ftol - tolerance in function value change
      func - function to be minimized
      Returns:
      minimum function value

    • powell

      public static double powell​(double[] p, double[][] xi, double ftol, int powell_itmax, Function<double[],​Double> func, List<Double> iterations)
      Minimization of a function func of n variables. Input consists of an initial starting point p[1..n]; an initial matrix xi[1..n][1..n], whose rows contain the initial set of directions (usually the n unit vectors); and ftol, the fractional tolerance in the function value such that failure to decrease by more than this amount on one iteration signals doneness. On output, p is set to the best point found, xi is the then-current direction set. The routine linmin is used. Based on Numerical Recipes ch. 10.5.
      Parameters:
      p - initial point
      xi - initial set of directions
      ftol - tolerance in function value change
      powell_itmax - maximum number of iterations for outer loop
      func - function to be minimized
      iterations - if not null, intermediate function values are added to the list at each iteration
      Returns:
      minimum function value

    • frprmn

      public static double frprmn​(double[] p, double ftol, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> dfunc)

    • frprmn

      public static double frprmn​(double[] p, double ftol, int frprmn_itmax, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> dfunc, List<Double> iterations)
      Conjugate gradient method for minimization. Given a starting point p[], Fletcher-Reeves-Polak-Ribiere minimization is performed on a function func, using its gradient as calculated by a routine dfunc. The convergence tolerance on the function value is input as ftol. Returned quantities are p (the location of the minimum), fret (the minimum value of the function). Based on NumericaL Recipes 10.6.
      Parameters:
      p - starting point
      ftol - tolerance on function value
      frprmn_itmax - maximum number of iterations
      func - function to be minimized
      dfunc - gradient
      iterations - records the successive minimums in the iterations (null ok)
      Returns:
      minimum function value

    • linmin

      public static double linmin​(double[] p, double[] xi, Function<double[],​Double> func)
      Given an n-dimensional point p[1..n] and an n-dimensional direction xi[1..n], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved.
      Returns:
      the value of func at the returned location p. This is actually all accomplished by calling the routines mnbrak and brent. Based on Numerical Recipes 10.5.

    • dlinmin

      public static double dlinmin​(double[] p, double[] xi, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> dfunc)
      Given an n-dimensional point p[] and an n-dimensional direction xi[], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved. Also returns as fret the value of func at the returned location p. This is actually all accomplished by calling the routines mnbrak and dbrent. Based on Numerical Recipes 10.6.
      Parameters:
      p -
      xi -
      func -
      dfunc -
      Returns:

    • armijo

      public static double armijo​(double[] x, double fx, double[] df, Function<double[],​Double> func)

    • gradientDescent

      public static double gradientDescent​(double[] x, double gtol, int gd_itmax, Function<double[],​Double> func, Function<double[],​double[]> gradient, List<Double> iterations)

    • numericalGradient

      public static double[] numericalGradient​(Function<double[],​Double> func, double[] x)
      Straightforward two-point estimation of partial derivatives; no guarantees for accuracy. (Don't do numerical derivation ...)
      Parameters:
      func - function for which gradient is calculated
      x - at this point
      Returns:
      vector of partial derivatives; same length as x
